description.narrative: This project therefore provides the platform/opportunity to (i) digitalize the lumos (create an electronic profile of the lumos for proper documentation of stakeholders, trading activities and revenue generation) and (ii) digitalize lumo transactions (the marketing, buying and selling of goods and services. (iii) and to build the Lumos back better through upgrading infrastructure in line with the new normal, while advancing gender equality by means of increasing women’s agency and participation in the Lumos’ recovery process.

Support public advocacy, awareness raising and sensitization on prevention and response via both new and traditional media platforms Support informal workers to reinstitute their jobs/livelihood Collaborate with informal sector to promote the manufacture, assembling, production and design of homegrown lifesaving solutions including disinfectants, sanitizers and masks for health care facilities in accordance with WHO guidelines Support informal worker efforts in fighting COVID-19, protecting jobs and safeguarding SDG progress Promote the aligning social protection to the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda Provide advice and technical assistance to support the Government to use social protection as a policy for sustainable development.

Activités spécifiques Covid-19 de l'Outcome 3 du portefeuille ODD16+ permettant de faire bénéficier communautés (jeunes, femmes et groupes vulnérables,) des efforts de développement
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: N/A

comment.narrative: - Soutien au Parlement tunisien pour lui permettre de continuer à exercer son rôle et son mandat pendant la phase de confinement (Produit 1.1. du portefeuille) : 217 députés et 83 membres du personnel de l'administration parlementaire disposent de moyens renforcés pour exercer leur rôle législatif et de contrôle pendant la phase de confinement - Soutien aux autorités locales afin de leur permettre de continuer à fournir les services publics locaux essentiels (gestion des déchets, nettoyage des espaces publics, services funéraires) (Output 1.3. du portefeuille) : 506 employé.e.s municipaux reçoivent un équipement de protection et du matériel d'hygiène leur permettant d'améliorer leurs conditions de travail pendant la phase de confinement et de réduire la probabilité de contamination et de diffusion du virus dans leurs communautés - Soutien à une série d’institutions clés (Conseil supérieur de la magistrature, Instance nationale de prévention de la torture et Instance nationale de lutte contre la traite des personnes) dans le développement de plans de continuité en cas de crises (Output 1.4.). - Soutien au ministère de l'intérieur pour la fourniture d'équipements de soins intensifs à l'hôpital de La Marsa afin de permettre le traitement des patients des forces de sécurité intérieure et de leurs dépendants (Output 1.5. du document de portefeuille) : L'hôpital ISF de La Marsa, qui dessert près de 10 000 agents déployés dans le Grand Tunis, est équipé de 6 unités de soins intensifs - Soutien à la Commission nationale de lutte contre le terrorisme dans la compréhension de l’évolution du discours de la haine dans les réseaux sociaux pendant le confinement (Produit 1.6) : Une recherche est lancée pour identifier comment les discours de haine en ligne étant liés au COVID-19 sont utilisés pour alimenter les divisions et finalement promouvoir l'extrémisme violent. Cette étude a pour objectif de permettre d’informer l’élaboration de stratégies préventives sur le discours alternatif. - Soutien au Comité national des prisons et de la rééducation pour la fabrication de matériel de protection pour les détenus, le personnel pénitentiaire et le personnel du ministère de la santé dans les ateliers qui existent dans quatre prisons (Output 2.2. du portefeuille) : 200 000 masques et 8650 combinaisons de protection ont été fabriqués au niveau de trois prisons dont celle des femmes de la Manouba. Ces équipements de protection sont au profit de 23 000 détenu.e.s, 7000 membres du personnel pénitencier, du Ministère de la Santé et des FSI. - Soutien à la société civile et aux communautés pour contribuer efficacement à la réponse Covid-19 (Outputs 1.8, 2.4., 2.6 et 2.7) : - Appui au ministère en charge des Droits de l’Homme et des Relations avec la Société Civile pour la mobilisation, l’équipement et le renforcement des capacités des bénévoles engagés dans la mise en œuvre de la campagne nationale de solidarité et d’aide aux populations vulnérables. - Les 16 comités locaux de sécurité (CLS) ont entrepris plus de 110 actions avec la société civile et les autorités locales. Ces actions ont facilité la collecte de dons, la désinfection des établissements publics et des hôpitaux, la fabrication et la distribution de masques et de combinaisons de protection, la distribution d'aides financières de l'État et de produits alimentaires de base aux plus vulnérables - La réorientation de 26 initiatives de la société civile autour de trois grands axes : i) la sensibilisation de la population aux mesures sanitaires ; ii) la prévention de la propagation du virus ; et iii) le soutien aux populations isolées et vulnérables, notamment les femmes et les personnes âgées. 400 jeunes volontaires ont été mobilisé.e.s et près de 30 000 personnes ont bénéficié des actions entreprises. - Soutien logistique aux services de la ministre chargée de la fonction publique pour piloter les dispositions relatives au télétravail en lien avec les priorités gouvernementales (Output 3.3.)

description.narrative: a. Number of comprehensive assessments report to identify MSMEs impacted by the pandemic and data base set up. b. 5000 youths (60% women) with enhanced awareness on vocational training and assisted with start-up grants for small businesses related to COVID-19 response including Hygiene and sanitation materials c. Number of online mobile platforms set up for MSMEs for enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvements. d. Number of integrated MSMEs with supply chains with industrial parks for better income. e. Number of “one window” service established by the Government in the regions on SMEs supported. f. Number of updated and need-based assessment reports on potential green jobs. g. Number of small enterprises directly impacted by the pandemic benefited from emergency COVID-19 support to revamp businesses and jobs for the youth (60% women). h. Number of youths (20,000; 60% women) engaged in cash for work through waste management and hygiene improvement interventions. i. Number of youths (60% women) in rural areas engaged on planting of agro-forestry trees in degraded areas through cash for work to enhance environmental conservation.

comment.narrative: a. There is very little data on the impact of the pandemic on MSMEs in order to set up a data base and enable small business to regain their productivity b. Small enterprises mostly of women owned are unable to become self-supportive and incapable due to COVID-19 pandemic c. Lack of functioning online mobile platform for MSMEs for an enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvement. d. Lack of integration of MSMEs with supply chains for industrial parks e. Lack of functional capacity of a “one window” service established by the Government in the regions on SMEs. f. Lack of updated and need-based assessment conducted, and potential green jobs documented. g. Lack of resources to provide support to pandemic impacted small enterprises to retain jobs. h. Insufficient resources to ensure proper waste management, good hygiene and jobs that benefit 20,000 youth (60% women) i. Lack of income for rural communities impacted by the pandemic

α. At least 1 socio-economic impact report on the pandemic is accessible and used to set up a data base on MSMEs. b. 5000 youths (60% women) are supported through vocational training and with business startup capital c. one functional online mobile platform for MSMEs is established /installed for enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvements. d. three or more MSMEs are integrated with supply chains through industrial parks. e. At least one “one window” services established by the Government in the regions on SMEs are reinforced through capacity building process. f. At least one updated and need-based assessment report on potential green jobs accessible. g. 500 small enterprises directly impacted by the pandemic are supported and led to 50,000 jobs retained. h. 20,000 youths (60% women) have received cash through cash for work on waste management and hygiene improvements i. 5000 youths (60% women) have engaged on planting of agro–forestry trees in degraded areas through cash for work

description.narrative:
(a) Number of BDS providers delivering innovative, including virtual services to informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures.
(b) Number of informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures accessing inovative and relevant BDS.
(c) % of informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures adapted disaster resselience stratgeies as part of their business plan.
(d) # of electronic platform available for making direct contribution to FNPF.
(e) % of project supported workers and entrepreneurs making contributions to FNPF through the electronic platform.
(f) # of workers and entrepreneurs associations formed in the creative industries and agricultural sub-sectors.
(g) % of supported associations linked to national workers and employers organisations.
(h ) # of policy recommendations to support informal sector workers and entreprenures progressed by national workers and employers organisations.

comment.narrative:
(a) Nil BDS providers delivering innovative, including virtual services to informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures.
(b) Nil number of informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures accessing inovative and relevant BDS.
(c) 0% of informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures adapted disaster resselience stratgeies as part of their business plan.
(d) # of electronic platform available for making direct contribution to FNPF.
(e) % of project supported workers and entrepreneurs making contributions to FNPF through the electronic platform.
(f) # of workers and entrepreneurs associations formed in the creative industries and agricultural sub-sectors.
(g) % of supported associations linked to national workers and employers organisations.
(h ) # of policy recommendations to support informal sector workers and entreprenures progressed by national workers and employers organisations.

(a) 3 BDS providers per country (b) 300 informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures accessing innovative and relevant BDS. (c) 50% of informal sector women and youth led creative-prenures and agri-prenures adapted disaster resilience strategies as part of their business plan.
(d) 1 electronic platform available per country for making direct contribution to National Provident Fund.
(e) At least 50% of project supported workers and entrepreneurs making contributions to FNPF through the electronic platform.

description.narrative: Enhanced COVID-19 protection through inclusive security governance in several targeted governorates in Yemen
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1 # of police personnel reached for sensitization and advocacy on human rights, gender equality and non-stigmatization during public health enforcement 2. # of women police trained 3 Legal guidance in place to frame GBV responses by the legal community, including judges, lawyers, prosecutors and paralegals 4. # of COVID-19-related law enforcement SOPs developed 5. # C-IED awareness raising activities and IED disposal training conducted

comment.narrative: 1. 500 police personnel reached for sensitization and advocacy on human rights, gender equality and non-stigmatization during public health enforcement 2. 200 women police trained 3. Legal guidance in place to frame GBV responses by the legal community, including judges, lawyers, prosecutors and paralegals 4. One COVID-19-related law enforcement SOPs developed 5. Four trainings, 48 bomb disposal officers

Q1 2021. No tangible results for the above-mentioned targets (1 to 5). Q1 2021 focused on planning the overall activities, including development of TOR for Responsible Party (RP) and selection of Responsible Parties (RPs).

description.narrative: Beirut Post-Blast Response: Supporting Inclusive and Integrated Recovery in Karantina
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The devastating explosion that originated at the Beirut Port in August 2020 culminated a series of major and successive crises facing the country: 1) the impact of the protracted Syria crisis, where Lebanon continues to host the largest refugee per capita population in the world; 2) an economic-fina

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Data management system established # of gender-inclusive neighborhood committees established and decisions included in the recovery response # of neighborhood improvement plans developed and implemented Number of shops/SMEs rehabilitated Number of equipment delivered to shops/SMEs Amount of cash support provided for stock recovery Amount of grants provided Number of workers employed Number of worker days generated Number of vulnerable beneficiaries (disaggregated by gender) accessing the health services #of people involved in memorialization and trauma healing theatre sessions # individuals provided with free legal/human rights assistance # of sustainable energy solutions implemented # tons of rubble treated number of houses rehabilitated number of historical buildings restored

comment.narrative: No data management and coordination system in place No formal mechanisms for community engagement in the recovery planning process Estimated 60 SMEs recovered No services provided to PWDs at Karantina hospital. Absence of essential services and reduction of capacity due to the damages incurred by the blast People of Karantina traumatized from the blast Karantina is composed of many groups and individuals at risk of having their rights violated Minimal rubble removal and treatment activities Estimated 400 residential units damaged

description.narrative: Climate Resilient Women Centric Economic Empowerment for Inclusive and Greener Post-COVID-19 Recovery
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: # of women owned and women centric MSMEs established contributing to green and blue economy in coastal and rural areas

comment.narrative: Project was approved in November 2020. Hence, there is no tangible result to report in 2020.

1. 500 households in all five regions provided with technical and other in-kind support (tools, production input, small equipment, raw material, kits, among others) to contain the COVID-19 triggered vulnerability and accelerate the relaunch of rural economic activities. 2. 10 women owned and women centric MSMEs established contributing to green and blue economy in coastal and rural areas; 3. 10 women user groups and mother groups built to manage a community-based agriculture resource center 4. 1 local and regional collection, distribution and sales centers established for locally produced, grown, processed or manufactured products 5. 1 women- and youth-led service-oriented businesses to link production and processing-based enterprise to the consumers

description.narrative: Output 1 will focus on completing a comprehensive assessment of the COVID-19 Emergency Response Coordination Platform (ERCP). This assessment will serve to define the nature and scope of the platform's scaling and expansion to be undertaken within the Government.The assessment will include identifying technological requirements, redesigning business processes; identifying and closing functional and institutional gender gaps, the financial resources required and overall capacity building and institutional strengthening.

activity-description.narrative: Doughnut economic model adaptation; Digital Readiness Assessment; Municipal service and data mapping; Municipal service and digitalization; Behavioural experiments and awareness raising.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.1. Yerevan City Portrait is developed and endorsed by Yerevan municipality 1.2. Number of partnerships established for downscaling the Doughnut Economic Model (DEAL, C40 cities, Yerevan municipality) 1.3. Advisory Council on gender equality, women & youth issues established adjunct to the Municipality 2.1. Completed local services mapping 2.2. Completed data mapping on municipal level 2.3. Completed digital readiness assessment 2.4. Number of selected services to be redesigned based on the identified criteria 2.5. Number of gender analysis systems established for sex-age disaggregated data collection 3.1. Research exercise among users based on design thinking methodology 3.2. Research exercise of business processes of the selected services to be redesigned 3.3. Prototypes of redesigned services based on research findings 3.4. Tested prototypes are digitalized 3.5. The ratio of online/offline use of services is shifted towards online through behavioral experiments 3.6. Piloted offline selected services 3.7. Established service management system

comment.narrative: The project started on 30 December 2020, so no activities were carried out in 2020.
The project started on 30 December 2020, so no activities were carried out in 2020.

1.1. Assessment of the Ukrainian’s economy and financial system exposure to the non-financial risks conducted, identification of the main threats arising from the EU Green Deal made 1.2. Recommendations on hot to financially and politically support participation of Ukraine at the EU Green Deal prepared. 1.3. Number of men and women from diverse groups targeted by conferences, webinars and training activities in the area of green recovery and green financing.
2.1. A working group on green and sustainable finance established. 2.2. Green Bond Standard to join European Green Deal (EGD) and facilitate mobilisation of the private green and sustainable finance developed. 2.3. Green Taxonomy to join European Green Deal (EGD) and facilitate mobilisation of the private green and sustainable finance developed.
3.1. Assessment of the existing IT-solutions on measuring carbon footprint conducted. 3.2. A guidance on how applicate the internal carbon pricing prepared. 3.3. Number of men and women from diverse groups targeted by conferences, webinars and training activities in the area of climate risk management and measuring the carbon footprint. 3.4. Number of the businesses that are covered by the IT-solution for assessing a carbon footprint.
